												This game is my go to time killer, it's not for everyone though.You should NOT buy this game IF you don't like spending  hours trying to perfect a level, or use 30 minutes on a level and then have the  game tell you that you took too long.Although this game is so rewarding when you pull off that insanely difficult  jump, or when you beat everyones high score. 												Please take time to read the whole review...Don't get me wrong, by itself Trials Fusion is a decent game - Great graphics, great scenery and keeps the elements of its predecessors without changing too much. However, as a person who has dedicated over 120 hours into Trials Evolution Gold Edition, I must say that Fusion is pretty underwhelming compared to it.First of all, there are significantly fewer levels in this game than there are in TEGE - it took me at least 20 hours to get the medal tally required to unlock the platinum medals, but in Fusion it only took me 4 hours. That's right, they took our beloved Trials franchise and decided to include DLC in it. It definitely feels like a dog move against us.Lastly, they decided to leave out the most essential feature when they released this game - online multiplayer! And only this year they decide they're finally going to release it? Pretty crap if you ask me.Final verdict - If you have played Trials Evolution Gold Edition for a while and feel like playing some new, different levels, buy this game when it's on sale, as if you ignore all of its flaws it's a pretty good game.If you have never played a trials game before, buy Trials Evolution Gold Edition as it is a lot more fun to play than this game.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Sale edit: Every DLC is on sale right now, this hasn't happened before, so take the very low price into account with my DLC reviews :)Awesome level MAX Edit: This isn't included in the season pass, and as yet I do not own it. I'll update this section with details on whether the DLC is worth a full price or not when I purchase it for myself. As for the introduced microtransactions, they're purely cosmetic and not required.IntroductionThis was the first Trials game I ever played, and it's great. Don't let the negative reviews put you off, most of them are negative simply because it uses Uplay, which I shall talk about further down the review.SettingFirst off, the environment in this game is stunning. For a game like Trials, in which you just ride your bike across level after level, you wouldn't expect this level of quality, the world looks like it's part of a much larger game. There's also plenty of variety, as you quickly move from the futuristic city to platforms in the sky, ancient ruins, outdoor courses, underwater bases and even the planet's core. There is also some slight hints of story included through a few characters talking throughout the game, which hint at how the world became like this. Gameplay It's trials. You drive your bike, tilt your weight and try to make it to the end as fast as possible and with as few failures as possible. Every level also has three challenges that encourage you to play differently, and some even involve minigames entirely different to how the game is usually played. The difficulty as you pass through the levels is done very well. By the time I was met with much harder obstacles, I'd already got a basic idea of how to surpass them, and not once did a death feel cheap.DLCThe DLCs add some nice extra content that also gives you a look at more of the world of Fusion, and provide some decent challenge. I wouldn't recommend buying them seperately, but if you don't want to buy the Deluxe Edition, here's a summary of their content and quality:2/10/15 Edit: Read the Deluxe Edition section for my opinion on prices! Riders of the Rustlands The first DLC and the weakest. Featuring only 6 levels, an FMX course and a mediocre minigame. - Not really worth £4 compared to the other DLCs, skip this one and get another. Empire of the Sky Same as above, 6 levels, FMX and a minigame. The levels are a bit better than Rustlands, but still not worth £4. If you've beat the game and want some more fun, get this DLC. Otherwise you can ignore it. Welcome to the Abyss Breaks the chain and includes 8 levels instead of 6, as well as the FMX and minigame at the end. This DLC gives an interesting look at an underwater empire that used to live under the ocean. Some story is delivered through another AI who speaks to you at certain points. The levels are of a higher standard than the first two DLCs, and I think barely justifies its £4 pricetag. Fire in the deep 9 levels, FMX and a minigame. In this DLC you are even further down, underneath the planet's core. As you move from level to level you go further underground, giving a nice indication of your progress through the DLC. There are also multiple secret recordings hidden around the levels, which give some extra information about the world, and what went on in the mines. Worth it. Fault One Zero Personally, I believe this is the best DLC. It drops one level and returns to 8 trials again, but the quality of the levels steps up greatly. This DLC has a focus on technology, much more so than previously shown, with teleporters, anti gravity machines and Mechs featuring. The levels in this DLC are very inventive, including  one that repeatedly glitches between looking normal, and a blue cyberspace-esque environment and  an interesting level in which you drive around inside three arcade machines! This DLC is definitely worth £4. After the Incident The sixth and final DLC. Same as above, 8 levels with an FMX and Minigame. One of my main disapointments with Trials Fusion was the lack of detail as to what was happening. I understand that this is a game solely based on a random guy riding a bike through obstacle courses, but with such an interesting world, with many deeper story elements hinted at throughout, I really wanted to learn more. After the Incident does so nicely. It's set in the future, when all the world is in ruins after the aforementioned "Incident". The levels all focus on fairly different areas, all destroyed or going through some form of crisis. Similar to Fire in the Deep, you can find secrets in the levels, which give you some backstory as to how all of this started. The way this is done is great, as  SynDI talks to you through a dating game text box, with amusing exagerated changes in her expression as she talks. If you want to know more about the world behind Fusion, or just want to play even more levels, this DLC is worth the money. Deluxe Edition  I'd like to point out that this game has gone on multiple sales, but not a single time have the DLC packs gone on discount themselves, and it doesn't look like they will at any time unfortunately. --In the most recent sale at the time of writing, all DLCs aside from Awesome Level MAX have been reduced to 99p, so I'd definitely recommend waiting for a sale before purchasing any DLCs-- As such, I highly recommend you get the Deluxe edition during a sale, I managed to pick it up for £10. Otherwise, if you beat the game and decide you want more, you will be paying a much higher price. Say you got the base game on sale for £6. Now if you got three of the DLCs, that'll cost you an extra £12. Half the DLC total DLC and you've spent £18 already. The Deluxe edition is a much better purchase (During a sale of course. The DLC is good but not worth £30!)Why the negative reviews?Now, there are three main flaws that have gave this game so many negative reviews. First main point is the multiplayer. I played the game entirely solo and had fun, I can't really comment on it.Secondly, people seem to be complaining about this being a bad port, and having a many performance issues. For reference, I ran the game on an i5 3570k, 8gb RAM and a GTX 770 with constant 60fps and no issues of any kind. The issue may be related to lower-end machines.And as for the last point, UPlay. The majority of these reviews are from people starting the game, seeing Uplay, closing it and leaving a bad review. I will say right here that if you avoid this game because of Uplay, you are stupid. But UPlay sucks! The impact of UPlay is nowhere near as bad as the reviews make it sound. You start the game on Steam, UPlay appears, takes a couple seconds to log in, then minimizes and starts the game. You only need to interact with it once in order to create an account, and after that you don't need to touch the thing, aside from closing it when you are done.EDIT: UPlay now does not even appear when you start a game through Steam. It minimizes itself. Seriously guys, the impact is so minimal it's not even worth arguing about!ConclusionAll in all, I recommend Trials Fusion to anyone who is an existing trials fan, or enjoys 2D games with high difficulty. Though the price is a little steep for the content on offer, so I'd suggest waiting for a sale and getting the deluxe edition. As earlier stated, it's much better value as the DLCs never get discounted, and only costed £4 (the price of a single DLC) more than the normal pack in the latest sale. And finally, do not avoid this game because of UPlay, there is no reason to.

Posted: October 9, 2014
												This game's alright... I'm not at all alright while playing it, but I still love it. After the rage wears off, the game gives you a good sense of accomplishment when you finally get that 0 fault gold medal run, especially on later (hard) stages.While Trials Fusion is a streamlined trials game (it is much, much easier than Evolution), there is still a good amount of hard tracks in the base game, and a few of them only the most persistent players will be able to "gold medal" (while others will rage quit out of the game and write a review...). There are 8 zones in the base game, and each one has 6 to 10 tracks in it (8 on average), that number is significantly increased with the season pass, which adds 6 new zones. Right now, 9/10/2014, the season pass only offers 3 zones, with 3 more on the way before May 2015. The game also includes a track editor, so you can create your own tracks, and you can easily access and play tracks built by other people online (which are pretty impressive from what I've seen/played).Now I'm not a big fan of Ubisoft's PC releases, because I usually get hit by poor optimization issues that plague a lot of their games at release, this game's performance however, pleasantly surprised me and put a big fat smile on my face, after the stutter fest that was Trials Evolution Gold Edition, I wasn't very hopeful going into this one. The game runs perfectly smooth maxed out on my machine, and the only stutter I got was on a graphically intensive track, while I had 2 video streams running in the background, after trying the same track without flash videos hogging my cpu, the stutter went away, and the game ran buttery smooth again.For reference, my PC specs are:i7 920 @3Ghzgtx660ti 2gb8gb ramwin7 64bitIt's worth mentioning that the game has a pretty good, yet weird sense of humor, for example whenever you finish a track, something funny and dumb is sure to happen, like the rider falling of his bike after he crosses the finish line, landing in the water and racing a cruise ship, or when you cross a finish line that's on top of a 2 story hut, the door closes behind you, and the hut starts flying off like a rocket. I also really enjoy the AI commentary (I guess you can call them the narrators), and the biker's yells and woohoos remind me of Homer Simpson.This game is a steal even at full price, and on a decent sale it should be a no-brainer if you played and liked previous Trials games, but I'm sure 2D platformer game enthusiasts would love it as well. As for the score, I'm giving it a 9/10.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												Trials Fusion is just a mindless blast of fun and mayhem. Get some friends together and it only multiplies it, but it's solid even by itself.Here's a video showcasing my shenanigans in this game for those who are curious. If not, just read the rest of the review below.


YouTube™ Video: Trials Fusion: Quick Look 

			Views: 2,146		

			Noble of Lost Pause takes a fun quick look at Trials Fusion. Watch gravity be the hardest boss in the game!		

I'll start by saying the gameplay is pretty simple, but challenging at the same time. The only thing you're doing is balancing your rider and your bike along a path while pounding the gas. However, the balancing part is the main problem and where all the challenge lies. The courses have you flying and leaping over all sorts of nonsensical obstacles, and landing it perfectly just doesn't happen sometimes. Even more so when you're trying to show off in front of your friends and botch the trick. But in my personal opinion, it's more fun failing than it actually is succeeding. It's hilarious watching my rider flop around because I was being a dope and got overzealous in my flips, which is a huge boon to the game because you're having a blast whether you're succeeding or failing miserably like I do sometimes.The game also doesn't feel cheap, nor feel like it cheats you out of anything. It's easy enough to get a silver medal on most tracks, but getting a gold is never too out of reach. It saddens me a little that doing tricks doesn't net you anything special besides cool points for yourself, but at the same time, it's one less thing I have to worry about if all I'm trying to do is unlock things. It allows you to play the game the way you want to, and having more options of playing the game is always better.And even when you run out of tracks to do in the game, there is a track creation tool that can make more and be shared with the comminity, so you don't have to worry about stuff to do. The game is even getting DLC in the future with more tracks if community stuff isn't your thing, so there's an option for you there as well.As far as negatives go, my complaints are very minor. While the stages themselves look amazing, all the stuff that's happening sometimes can be a little distracting from what you're doing. Or sometimes even the reverse is true, that you're so focused on your bike, you don't notice all the stuff happening around you when you want to see it. Another thing is that all of the stuff happeing in the background doesn't really effect what you're doing in the foreground. It's just fluff. I think it would've added a bit more diversity and dynamics if the stage interacted with the rider more.There's also still a few bugs in the game or poor optimization. When I went to the create tool, it locked up my comp, which is a beast and shouldn't have any trouble loading anything. The same goes with how long it takes to select a ride at the beginning of the stages. I just stare at a black screen for a good while before something eventually pops up. But thankfully you can just press A to go to the course regardless, so it isn't that big of a deal.So to sum it up, for 20 dollars, you're gonna have a blast with this title. It looks good, feels good, has a great sense of humor (the endings and the announcer make me laugh quite a bit), has potential to grow, and is fun with friends. Definitely pick this up, even more so when it goes on sale.

It has bikes, a screaming guy, the most hilarious tricksystem I've ever seen, and FUUUTUREEEEE!!!For the people that owned Trials Evolution:If you had a fun time with Trials Evolution I'm 100% sure you'll love Fusion, the game has been revamped, a whole set of new bikes, new courses, a new world, new music, and CHALLENGES !In summary, if you love Evolution, Fusion is no difference, its familiar, funky music, new bikes, tracks and what not.For the people that are new to the Trials series:Let me tell you that this game is not for the fainted hearts, this game is easy but it gets tougher and tougher, until you say F*ck this I quit. Ofcourse, the more you'll play the more you'll get familiar with the physics on the bike, the tracks and other useful tips and tricks you'll pick up on while playing.- I highly recommend playing this with a controller, either Xbox or PS3 (Get an emulator that emulates your ps3 controller to x360) Because while progressing through the game, there are a lot of climbs, bunnyhops and other hard tricks you'll have to pull of precise in order to place some good times on the scoreboard and finishing faultless, therefore I'd highly recommend a controller more than a clunky keyboard.- The game looks really colorful, it's like a rainbow took a♥♥♥♥♥♥on the game, thats how colorful it is, and it's pretty, really pretty.Its an absolute joy and feast for your eyes.Never the less screw the graphics cuz gameplay > graphics amirite? If you said no then smh.- The game starts easily like I said but when progressing it gets more difficult on a level of "Not finishable" If you're brand new and having issues with this platformer.The physics play a huge roll in this game which is why it takes skill to successfully and flawlessly play and finish this game.- Challenges that have been added in the game, which are mini tasks you CAN do (Not need to) for extra XP are also lots of fun and sometimes really stressful. They make you feel super happy once you've completed it. They make you feel annoyed and boiling when you screw it up in the end.Note: I suck at reviews, never done one but I'm just typing whatever comes to mind and what I would like to know about a game I'm willing to buy.- Customisation has been redone, you can now pick from multiple sets of "armor/suits" that are unlockable by finishing tracks, earning xp or doing certain tasks. The only negative thing that I can think of is that you can not save the color you have picked for example on your shirt, to match that with your pants/helmet... Customisation is a cool addon, also the bikes are again modifyable (if that's a word >.<) in which you unlock bodykits and wheels to customize them. That's pretty cool if you ask me.- Two slightly annoying things that I've noticed while playing this (Also been confirmed by other friends that play trials) The loading time on the Garage/customisation takes a while (10-20s) so that could be a little issue if you're inpatient.- If you do happen to buy the game, let me tell you "WELCOME TO THE FUTURE" on every single start up. It makes me laugh but can get annoying if you pick up on it.In summary: The game handles great, controller recommended, great visuals, easy to pick up and play, hard to master, great value with a lot of grinding on challenges that are added to each and EVERY track (Yes even extreme tracks). If you're still not sure I recommend reading some other reviews that are more helpful than mine isI tried my best >:3Thank you

												Trials Fusion is the latest installment in what has generally been a game that offers a simple premise but provides a lot of gameplay punch.  While there aspects of Fusion that I am greatly impressed with, there are a few things that I am unhappy with. For those unfamiliar, the Trials games are a very simple premise. You're riding a motorbike (along with other vehicles in Fusion) across a large variety of tracks with physics being the ultimate gameplay component. You have to control the bike properly or you will wipe out.....A LOT!I've broken this into a simple pros/cons list for anyone that has tl;dr issues :-)Pros:+ Looks fantastic. The colors are rich and have real pop to them. If you can play this in Ultra at the highest resolution you're in for a treat, even at lower resolutions it still is great eye candy+ Base game course design is interesting for the most part and the futuristic setting adds more than I thought it would.+ Trick/FX gameplay styles really add to the depth and encourage playing tracks multiple times with both fastest times and trick scores being seperate goals.+ A ton of community made tracks at your fingertips.Cons:- Pricey DLC with the season pass costing the same price as the base game making MSRP for both base and season pass (a.k.a. Deluxe Edition) just $20 less than a AAA title. There have been two DLC packs released thus far with more to come.- Some base game courses are much shorter than you'd expect.- Lacks the challenge at the lower levels that earlier Trials titles brought. Seems watered down for casuals/newcomers in respects. The physics are still brutal depending on course, but definitely easier to get the hang of. ATVs are disgustingly easy.-  Four months after release and online multiplayer is still not in the game, yet is promised by the developer. This is UNACCEPTABLE when being advertised as having multiplayer especially at the cost of the full package. Local multiplayer only at the moment (8/23/14 is the date of this review).- Tedious unlocking system.- There seems to be some measure of a "story" mode to the single player game where you're regularly spoken to by a female AI similar to GlaDOS of the Portal games, except the Trials AI lady lacks the wit of that classic character and is generally just grating.Let me be clear, while my cons are glaring, I do not regret my purchase of this game. I have a real soft spot for this series and have gotten a lot of mileage out of the earlier titles and am going to continue to play this one as it plays well and I can't overstate how great it looks. I was first introduced to Trials when it came out on Xbox 360 Arcade and I put well over 100 hours into that iteration of the game. I hesitated on this new one until I upgraded my hardware and now that I have, I am very glad I waited at least until then.  That being said, unless you are like me and a fan of the Trials series and know what you're getting into, do yourself a favor and hold off until this is on sale. I recommend this with a caveat. Definitely pick it up when on sale, but unless you're really into the series/gameplay style, you're fine waiting.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												This is not a terrible game by any means, but it feels like a definite step back from the previous installment and, by comparison especially, a lousy value proposition.The tracks are significantly fewer and blander, and that's not balanced out by the new mechanisms.Doing tricks seems to be based on your angle and the input on the right stick, but it feels pretty sketchy/inconsistent. The stages built around doing those tricks for points are too unforgiving: the checkpointing means you only get one shot at each jump trick, so any failed attempt means you've lost a potential 20% or so points for that stage. Maybe losing your multiplier would have been enough of a deterrent; as it stands, falling is too easy and too costly, so it makes sense to play it safe -- and that's boring, especially for a mode that's supposed to be a bit more crazy than the precision driving at the core of the franchise. Uniracers did it first and better, basically.'Challenges' are either Easter eggs hard to figure out without a guide, or require feats like finishing with zero fault while doing 10 tricks or never letting go of the gas pedal. That's one way to stretch playtime over a small number of tracks...Tournaments are one thing that's improved, though: they're time-limited and renewed every few hours, which is a good encouragement to participate and try to rank high.Now that the first piece of DLC (out of a planned 6) is out, it's obvious that we can't count on them to fix the fundamental problem of there not being enough content: each will be the size of a world, so 6 regular tracks and 2 gimmicky ones (and the first pack is boring like the rest, too).Are RedLynx / Ubi counting on player-created content to pick up the slack? Trying to find really good content is still a crapshoot though -- you can only rely on the 'featured' categories, very basic filters, or a percentage of positive reviews. There's quite a few enjoyable enough tracks, some with clever moments, but few if any are comparable in quality to the dev-made tracks from Trials Evolution, and you have to be in the mood to rummage around for them.It pains me to say it, but this is a disappointment. Just get Trials Evolution, and don't get Fusion until you've played so much Evo you're sick of it. And even then, be aware it's not great value at full price.

content:
Posted: March 24
												A great new entry in the line of Trials games.A unique and addictive mix of puzzle, physics and racing; which RedLynx has been mastering for what must be a decade now. I've been playing the RedLynx trials games since waaay back when they were just 2D Flash games; so they've come a looong way.However - I ride a motorcycle daily, still do trials biking on my bicycle, and have ridden actual Trials motorcycles, and I actually prefer the handling of it's predecessor: "Trials Evolution".PROSThe prettiest graphics of any Trials game to date; with fantastic gameplay to match.There's a wide range of beautiful environments and props for you to not only race in, but also create your own tracks in (with a bewildering amount of customisation). Your rides and riders can be personalised too, with (most) items being unlocked with progress and paid for with the in-game currency you earn. The rider can now do tricks in midair (once you unlock them) for that extra XP and show(off)manship. Tracks are varied, clever and engaging. And for those hardcore completionists, there's three side achievements for every track which range from simple to-dos to entire minigames. Lots of extra fun and value. Oh, and in case you didn't know, there are also Online and Local multiplayer modes too.CONSHandling that can be hard to understand and predict.I will say, the bikes move at a more realistic pace than ever before, feeling like they have real weight an inertia. But hit a bump or land from a drop, and sometimes those physics go out the window with a bike that surges and bounces like a space hopper, or jams/judders in a way that seems to stall the bike. Evolution had a bit of this too, but it made sense as the bikes felt light and twitchy. But when a hefty bike does it, it's hard to react, and harder to counter (the heavier bikes mean less airborne control). Performance also struggles too - The game isn't overly complicated, but it seems quite demanding on CPU and GPU power for what you get.OVERALLA great time wasting and skill honing game for people of all ages and gaming levels. Definitely worth buying if you see it on sale, but you may as well skip Steam and get in from uPlay directly (as you have to use uPlay anyway). However, if you're rig isn't very powerful, you'd be better served getting Trials Evolution - it's just as much fun, and probably better value.

So it requires a certain degree skill to fully enjoy but in my opinion it is extremely satisfying to see yourself getting better and beating that one hard track you've been stuck for so long.The game is not without it's problems: Uplay is mandatory and still a piece of sh*t that nobody wants, micro-transactions (luckily only for cosmetics), DLCs are pretty expensive for the amount of content they offer (best get them on sale), multiplayer is dead due to being added really late paired with PC having lowest audience for Trials games and also a controller is required because keyboard controls are next to useless.Many Trials veterans say that Evolution is better and more worth playing over Fusion for various reasons and they're probably right but I wouldn't know since I never got into Evolution when it came out on PC. The futuristic setting, electronic music and the ambiguous hidden story of Fusion was more interesting to me than bland old warehouses in a desert valley accompanied by rock music...But I'm in the minority who cares about that stuff so this review is simply from a Trials noob who enjoy the game for what it is despite it's faults :)

												I'd love to hate this game, but I simply can't. As the matter of fact - I love it. At least the first 30 minutes of each gameplay session, until frustration takes the best of me. Unlike other titles, where frustration comes from bad gameplay mechanics, clunky controls or just plain bugs - this game has none of those. Frustration comes only from your own mistakes and lack of focus and patience. I had no problem with the BEGINNER and EASY difficulty mode tracks, whereas in MEDIUM, I first took the time to learn the track and adapt to the ever-changing layout. HARD is where things got really painful. Let's just say that I had to repeat one track a hundred times to get the gold medal. Frustration was followed by a great sense of achievement. I find the new FMX trick system fun, but very difficult or just needed to get used to. One more problem, mentioned by most Steam users: Uplay. Being forced to use two types of DRM is ridiculous and Uplay sucks in general. Sometimes it takes ages to load certain data (bikes, rider accessories and the list of tracks) from the cloud. I bought this game mainly for the purpose of local co-op so I was devastated to find out that you weren't able to play the user-created tracks with your friends. After the latest patch they finally implemented that feature so hopefully we'll have more than the default 10 tracks to enjoy. To sum things up, I enjoy most of the features of Trials: Fusion. Just two things need to go: my lack of skill and Uplay. 9/10

												I first saw this game when TheBlazeJP did a 100% speedrun during #SGDQ2014,and that speedrun/his speedruns of other Trials games was what got me into playing Trials in the first place,with Fusion being my very first Trials game I've played myself.This game is one of those games where it's addicting and frusterating as hell at the same time(I can guarantee that after 10 hours of playing at the time of this review,trying to get most of the gold medals),but it's really fun regardless.The controls aren't actually that hard to get used to because they're a Happy Wheels style,I guess the only wonky thing being the FMX,but for me the FMX wasn't a huge deal.The skill games are really interesting,each skill game(and each track)having it's own quirks,and those along with the Rider's shouts during every track are some of the funniest/most entertaining parts of the gameIf you're looking for a game that's fun but still really challenging,seriously get this or Evolution,you won't regret it10/10 from me :)

A CONTROLLER IS RECOMMENDED, BUT NOT REQUIRED!If you've played these games before, skip this section:The Trials series is a physics based "platformer" racing title where you can race against friends and have the results be a fraction of a second off. The game can get pretty difficult and the map makers can turn the game into something entirely different. The games require uPlay as a second DRM, but if you just want one DRM, you can buy it from uPlay directly (and might save money doing so, as Ubisoft wants their uPlay service to grow bigger.) You'd like this game if you are into racing and competiting, though you might still love it if you hate typical racing games.For a comparison to Trials Evolution, the last Trials game:Pros:- Track editor is miles ahead of the older editor, meaning cooler content if you don't like to edit your own tracks.- You can do cool stuns in midair, used in a nice points-based "race."- Can customize your biker and your vehicle, including the new ATV.- Challenges to complete on every map with very unique challenges on certain maps.- Hidden secrets on some maps.- SQUIRRELS!Cons:- What is optimization? Where did you take my frames? Why did you steal them?- The opening theme will get annoyingly stuck in your head if you don't move past it fast... WE'LL GO TO THE FUTURE! MAN! MACHINE! THE FUSION! ...WELCOME TO THE FUTURE! *Repeat 100 times*- Currently only local multiplayer, but there are ghosts of friends to race against (Online MP will be patched in later.)- Unyielding (beat track without tilting; use only gas and brake and never crashing) and Full Throttle (Never let go of gas and never fault) challenges can go ♥♥♥♥ themselves... Might be a pro if you're a masochist.

content:
Posted: January 18
												Trials Fusion has quietly become something of a minor masterpiece. With the normal content plus season pass and MAX DLC there are a pile of things to do in the game, and it should keep any player busy for at least a solid 40 hours. We haven't even touched the 20k plus community tracks. From the active online through to campaign and whatever else you need, there really isn't any way you could go wrong with the MAX edition, which includes all the DLC plus the new MAX stuff for 40 bucks. This will obviously drop in price on certain sales. I honestly have very few complaints at this point in time. So let's discuss a few things:A lot of the cranky reviews cite either Uplay or the newest DLC, released long after a the yearly season pass, as problems that make them feel angry and mad. Neither of these issues is even the slightest bit of a problem anymore. If Uplay is not running correctly for you in 2015 it's your own fault. I have absolutely zero problems with it and haven't had any major problems with it for well over a year. It's a solid service, if unneeded, and really it doesn't belong in reviews for this game anymore.The season pass has expired. It was never meant to be a free DLC for life kind of thing. Only an idiot would keep thinking that a season pass somehow connotates free DLC for life. The new content is suitably priced anyway. Taken as a whole there are literally no problems with this game. At its release I could definitely agree it was a little lighter on content and the price was too expensive for not having a functional multiplayer; as well it was buggy and unfinished. But that simply is not the case anymore. Everything you would ever need is now included in the game, but polished to a high degree.The unlocks are decent and the various bike upgrades and ability to change colors and wheels among other things is a nice feature to keep you busy. There are a decent amount of extras for those interested that kind of stuff. You can use acorns, the new currency, to buy special additions like new body styles, outfits, and faces. You also unlock a decent amount of stuff just from normal playtime with the original currency. Acorns currency can now be purchased for cash if choose to do so. Leveling up in game seems to grant a decent amount of acorns as well.The meat of the game I am very happy to say is very solid. Graphics have been given a large boost and it shows throughout the incredibly varied environments. With the season pass you have access to a multitude of different locales and each has its own vibe that is fairly unique. As far as comparing this to Evolution Gold well this one is a lot different. Fusion is more extreme, with the themes of the environments and tracks taking on a totally appreciated craziness that really never lets you down. Both games are worth owning.Evolution is more grounded, where as this one just goes for glory and throws in some very imaginitive and well-constructed tracks that take you from the fiery pits of hell to the most futuristic skyscrapers of an advanced civilization. And everything in between. There is no game that does racing quite like the Trials series, and the devs have seriously stepped up their game.There are the usual medals to earn, but there is also three achievements on each stage that can find you hunting down squirrels or activating secret switches for special achievements. These will keep a lot of people busy that have gotten their golds the first couple times through.Besides getting gold medals, the idea is that you may want to try and compete on the leaderboards. Cracking a top 5K time will definitely give you the challenge you need and should entertain the skill levels of all players. Add in some wonderful multplayer action and dozens of hours will pass before you get tired of this one.I run this in 4K with a single 970 on the highest settings and it mostly holds a stable 60FPS. A few drops here and there on certain courses. It's a beauty of a game for sure. It might have some nitpicks here and there, but for the most part no Trials game has ever looked even close to this lovely.All in all this is now a great game. Support for Fusion continues and multiplayer is still very active. So get on it. It's worth every penny.

The games require uPlay as a second DRM, but if you just want one DRM, you can buy it from uPlay directly (and might save money doing so, as Ubisoft wants their uPlay service to grow bigger.) You'd like this game if you are into racing and competiting, though you might still love it if you hate typical racing games.For a comparison to Trials Evolution, the last Trials game:Pros:- Track editor is miles ahead of the older editor, meaning cooler content if you don't like to edit your own tracks.- You can do cool stuns in midair, used in a nice points-based "race."- Can customize your biker and your vehicle, including the new ATV.- Challenges to complete on every map with very unique challenges on certain maps.- Hidden secrets on some maps.- SQUIRRELS!Cons:- What is optimization? Where did you take my frames? Why did you steal them?- The opening theme will get annoyingly stuck in your head if you don't move past it fast... WE'LL GO TO THE FUTURE! MAN! MACHINE! THE FUSION! ...WELCOME TO THE FUTURE! *Repeat 100 times*- Currently only local multiplayer, but there are ghosts of friends to race against (Online MP will be patched in later.)- Unyielding (beat track without tilting; use only gas and brake and never crashing) and Full Throttle (Never let go of gas and never fault) challenges can go ♥♥♥♥ themselves... Might be a pro if you're a masochist.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Trials Fusion is an excellent entry to the series. Here's why:RedLynx tried something different this time around, and it works quite well. The trick system is an excellent feature put into the game. It promotes replayability of tracks by having the user see how "flashy" of a run they can nail and show off to their friends. It's based off of the famous RedLynx physics engine, making it intuitive, nice to look at, and at some points, silly to observe what may happen during a crash.But beyond the trick system, there's even more in terms of the traditional trials game. There's the usual spike in difficulty, where the last few groups of levels WILL test your patience, skill, and sanity. The levels themselves still keep their usual charm; being put in wacky/amazing environments, seeing things interact around you, it's all here. The environments all look great and there's enough variety to keep you happy.Now there are trick runs, where you have to see how many points you can get on a special track designated for this new system. I like this, because sometimes you want to do tricks on the normal tracks, but you know it may hurt your time. It seems they're trying to cater to those who like to have a little fun in between the serious time trials, and I respect their approach to it. It works for them.Skill games are back, and they're as fun and silly as ever. I don't agree how they made them a requirement this time around, but it's not the biggest issue in the worldEach of the bikes actually has a specific purpose and will be used depending on which track you're participating in. This is WONDERFUL. I remember in evolution you would use one or two bikes, because the only things the new ones did was have more power. I REALLY appreciate RedLynx making each bike unique and useable. There's some really nice biker customization as well. Lots of cool, future-y outfits to choose from. I'm really excited excited to see where the DLC takes this game. Although the game had a less-than-stellar launch, I'm still very happy with this product, and cannot wait to play through more trials. It feels like a trials game through-and-through to me, and that's what matters. It's a quality product that will only get better with more tweaking and additional content. I believe this is completely worth your money if you are a fan of the series.

No experience with the previous Trials games is necessary to instantly (well, after dealing with Uplay) enjoy this game. Unlike traditional racing games, there is no steering. You control only acceleration, braking, and leaning on your supercharged motorcross bike, in an attempt to finish insane levels or interesting challenges. Before you know it, you'll be mashing the convenient "instantly restart level" or "instantly restart at checkpoint" buttons as you try to figure out how to get just a little more air off that one jump, how to avoid faceplanting on that log, or how to keep up with your friend's ghosts. It is easy to get caught up in the search for perfection on each level because the gameplay is so tight, fun, and rewarding. Highly recommend! WELCOME TO THE FUUTURE

Posted: July 2, 2015
												So, after reading alot of reviews of the Trials series and this game in particular, i feel obligated to write one on my own.Many people had a huge problem with Ubisoft and their way to market their games, in fact those people hate on Trials Fusion just because it uses Uplay. The game is published by Ubisoft, i do not know why you would think they wouldnt put it on their own PC distribution service and account control service. Yes Uplay is sometimes broken, but those times are not THAT often, it happens  here and there, and Ubisoft doesnt seem to give a♥♥♥♥♥♥ But really, i dont want to review the Publisher or the Developers, which both chose to run this game on the platform.The Game Itself:- a very skillbased "racing" game, where the point is more or less to drive through a track with no mistakes, only after that the time really matters- has alot of content (though the price with the DLC is pretty high, compared to a triple a title it matches though)-> User created content pushes the game forward to a pretty high replay value (which mostly explains my playtime)Most negative aspects about it:- lack of content of the original game (no dlcs) compared to evolution- no ways of communication directly through the game- the multiplayer is pretty lagged out (though it is much better than evolution)Overall, they needed too long for the game to be at this state (which is a pretty definitve version on how a trials game needs to feel like), it felt like a beta for about a year into it. The developers did not abandon the game though and continued to give (free) content for the players to enjoy. With this in mind, i can only say it is one of my most beloved games today, for its high skillcap and active community, which still produces some great quality tracks.

Generally I would say the soundtrack of fusion is a lot worse than that of evolution. it has it's positives but it really couldn't get me as psyched as evolutions. Also, it feels easier. The falls are softer and the bikes are easier to handle. Some would say that's a good thing but i really don't think it is. trials is like dark souls, a game to tear your hair out at. Whereas this I breezed through until the extreme levels. Overall I'd really recommend this game, but maybe not for £16. Under a tenner would be an amazing price however.

												I've been a fan of the Trials series for a few years now, but I always run into the same problem. I literary fly through all the easy and medium levels, but when I start the hard ones, the game's just over for me. I have to spend hours to get one done, and have use too many checkpoints. Easy and medium levels I get done in one go most of the times, all gold medals, but the leap to hard is just too much for me.That being said, the game looks amazing and the futuristic style is wonderful.The addition of the tricks didn't feel all that great to me. I like the idea of it, but the excecution can be worked on. Or maybe it's my controller, I don't know.Adding the skill levels at the end of every chapter was new to me, too, and fun! But a lot of times it's hard to understand what they want you to do or the learning curve is to steap. I had a hard time getting trough the one where you had to do tricks before you hit the ground. My rider was flying around like a rag doll, getting stuck on every part of the bike.The ATV's look great, but don't use them online! They're horrible to jump with. It's just the raw power you use them  for.

content:
Posted: February 15
												Although the physics and controls in Trials Fusion remain as good as they are in in previous titles; the whole game feels uninspired and unimaginative when compared to trials evolution. Sure FMX is now a thing and some may like that, but the entire theme of the game is future and nothing but future So after 60 or so tracks they all start to blur into one big yet slightly different track. I'd be fine with this if the tracks flowed nicely but they just aren't fun or challenging. Except the ninja tracks maybe but they verge closer to irritating rather than of more finely tuned Inferno III of days past. Perhaps if you're new to the series this game would be excellent, but after many hundreds of hours on Evolution I couldnt say the same.Tl;dr The game feels rushed. Pushed out quickly to make money without forsight into what made the last two games fun. Buy Trials evolution gold edition. A game made before Ubisoft fully dug their claws into Redlynx. Never go full Ubisoft.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												I love Trials games. My first was Trials 2: Second Edition back in like 2008. I got the demo, played the crap out of it, and bought the game. Many hours went into it, and I was really excited when I saw Trials Evolution: Gold Edition was coming out, and bought it as soon as it did. This game was AMAZING. The soundtrack was fantastic, the graphics were great, the rider customization was fun, the tracks were awesome, it was, overall, far and above Trials 2: Second Edition's minimalistic style. Then I saw Urban Trial Freestyle, and bought that. Great game, though short, and nowhere near as awesome as Trials Evolution. Once I had all of them cleared, I saw on Facebook that Trials Fusion was in the works, and excitedly waited for it's release. After pre-ordering this game, and launching it the first time, I was immediately disappointed. The soundtrack is terrible (maybe not a big deal for you), loading took forever, and the bikes/rider/maps/tracks/menus all look really thrown together without much thought. My opinion, of course, but if you're going to get a Trials game, get Trials Evolution: Gold Edition. That game is the SH**.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												It always really bugs me when people low-ball the ratings for things because it didn't work for them. But in this case I think the technical issues are bad enough to be a non-starter. To clarify, the underlying game is a blast, from what I played, but to get 25 minutes of gameplay I had to put in about 3 hours of troubleshooting across two different (and very normal) computers, a PC and a laptop. There's a solid mix of server problems (uPlay AND another Ubisoft connection, both of which can, and for me did, fail often) which immediately reset your saved progress (it's always-online), graphics problems, and start up problems; all persistent across both computers. More irritating, the demo worked fine after a bit of work, and the full game did not: the demo uses uPlay but seems to save itself a lot of trouble by not attaching your progress to your account.I love the hell out of trials. But this game is hard enough to even start playing to make me wary of any future uPlay thing. It's more headache than the fun is worth.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												The game by itself is amazing and the $/hour value is insane with all the content you get from used created content, but there's a slight flaw which is best explained with an example:1. Decide to play the game.2. uDontPlay update3. Launch game - unskippable logos, but that's okay they're short.4. Preload before the main menu. Okay, could've done that during splash screens, but okay.5. Connecting to Ubisoft servers.....6. Still connecting.7. Failed to connect to Ubisoft servers, hit retry,8. Finally connected to Ubisoft servers, yay.9. Browse around the menus checking for new stuff.10. Random freeze, Ctrl+Alt+Del => End task.11. Wait for uDontPlay to do some bs before it shuts down.12. Relaunch game, surprisingly uDontPlay hasn't been updated since then.13. Splash screen logos, preload, connecting to Ubisoft servers.14. Failed to connect to Ubisoft servers, hit retry.15. Go straight for playing this time, let's see the new content.16. Spend ~2minutes to complete the first medium map in the new pack, loving it!17. Autosave after the level completion takes about as much time as the level itself.18. Lost connection to the Ubisoft servers............. That explains it.19. Hit retry, twice this time, before it actually works.20. Back, back, back, back, quit game.That's ~15-20 minutes of Ubisoft bullcrap to play two minutes of an otherwise solid game.Guess I'll try again in a couple months.... but every time I try to pick this game back up it's the same reason that makes me shelve it and that's uDontPlay.I'll admit, the freeze could've been a bug from Redlynx's side, but I wouldn't be surprised if Ubisoft DRM is so well integrated that it is the reason why the menus are so slow to swap inbetween to begin with.Setting up Excitebike on a NES emulator from scratch would probably take less time than each fresh launch of Trials through uPlay after a prolongued absence.TL;DR Great game that's close to unplayable thanks to a U shaped anchor.

												I'm a bit sad that I can't really reccommend this. I wanted more Trials, just to get rid of the shakes, but this.. This is most likely not the "More Trials!" you are looking for. Play Trials Evloution instead, if you have not done so and/or wait for the next one, where they hopefully tune some of the stuff back to "functionaltiy over visuals".Pros:- Graphics are amazing. Really, really pretty.- Still the same great Trials physics, bike handling feels almost exactly like the previous onesCons:- UPLAY-- This piece of garbage. BigPicture & COntroller -> Start any UPlay game -> Wait for Uplay updates & start looking for the mouse to click "Start". The day UPlay dies will be a happy one. Make a suicide pact with Origin please, why don't you. - Visuals over functionality-- Camera too often shows the scenery instead of the track you are about to land on-- Performance was never great with the Trials games, but because of the grat graphics and their camera work, Fusion performs HORRIBLE at times - which really sucks in a skill based "pixel perfect" thing, when you fail because of lag/hitches- "Trick Mode" is just bad. Right stick to perform stunts w/ the bike while in the air. Sounds nice, controlls horrbily. HORRIBLY.-- These levels are mandatory and mixed in with the normal Trials stuff and that sucks, because it just does not work wellI like trials more than I'd normaly publicly admit to, but this.. Yes, Trials should feel frustrating. But not because some Designer went "Hey stop showing so much of the track, show the background, we spent a lot of money making this!". They essentially broke their game with that attitude, about 50% of all levels I have played have had this. I am at about halway through, and between that and the Trick stuff, this is it for me, and I am actually a bit sad about this.. I want more real Trials.. :/Also, that intro Song.. O.oNext time, just make Trials Evloution 2, yes? Everyone will love you again and actually play your game..Thanks! :)

												I know I havn't put much time into this game, but first impressions are key.It runs well on my PC and looks stunning, however... My friends are struggling to run the game without it seeming like its in slow-motion. Bad optimization? I'm not sure.The feel of the game isn't like Evolution, I found myself feeling 'floaty' weak and the handling between bike seems a bit samey, which If I can recall, In an interview 'we have put in a lot of time making the game better but still feel like trials'. It doesn't feel like Trials.The main reason I feel robbed is that there is NO ONLINE MULTIPLAYER!!! Only local. What the heck is with that?! Me and my friends all bought this expecting to race eachother and have a laugh like we used to.Please add online multiplayer and fix this optimization issue my friends and A LOT of other people are having. Seeing as we had to wait longer for it to come out on PC I was expecting much better for a £15.99 title. Wouldn't even pay a tenna for this how it stands as of now.Don't get me wrong, it looks lovely and level design is outstanding. Recommend if your looking for a single player experiance, running on a good PC and have no attatchment to previous Trials titles. But not many of us are those people.

												Having liked this genre of games in the past.. I really went in wanting to like this game. From the onset it looked like similar games, such as trial evolution, etc.. but much more massive in scale. Well, it is massive... that is for sure. It has tons of tracks, content, and multiplayer.. but along the way it lost it's fun, challenge, and excitement and ends up being a poor reproduction of a classic. Whereas in previous games, you could mess up and still not crash, or choose your path, etc.. this game is exteremly linear.. a do it this way or die pattern quickly emerges. That ruins all the fun and charm of the previous games. So after a few basic levels.. you start getting it.. and once you realize it is.. ok.. do this now.. then do this. ok now this.. it becomes boring and bland. Save your money and pick up trials evolution or one of the other ones.. as this one, try as it might, is actually the worst of the lot.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												The game has a really good and fun way of playing and riding a motor bike, which makes the gameplay very good.The levels get very hard, most gamers won't be able to finish the entire single player campaign. I don't know if I find this very fun or not, because it's good to have a challenging game but this makes it a rage game, which I don't really like. Of course you could always just not finish the single player and move on to the custom maps but most of those are very hard aswell, so you are ♥♥♥♥ed either way.But the real problem for me, and the reason why I don't recommend it is, the local multiplayer supercross.In the prequel (trials evo) you had 10 or so standard supercross tracks and you could download a bunch of custom ones.In this game, you also have 10 or so standard supercross tracks but you can't download any custom supercross maps.This makes the supercross very lame very fast and is the reason why I won't buy another trials game if they don't implement it anymore.TLDR:If you like a challenge and you liked the old trials evo's singleplayer maps you will really like this game.But if you want to play with your friends, don't buy it and stay with evo.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												It's a good game, but it's not as good as Trials Evolution. That game was very long and offered so much deversity in the modes and level design. Add the crazy amount of unique user created levels, multiplayer and you have a classic.Cons - Fusion is a pretty short game and the heavy handed futuristic theme is off putting after a while. If I have to hear that, welcome to future song one more time, ugh! The DLC has been pretty nice but they're short levels and not worth the price. The selection of user created levels is limited and not very interesting so far. No online multiplayer and the local multiplayer is a shallow experience. The later levels get ridiculously hard.Pros - It's still a Trials game and the controls are awesome. The new trick feature done with the analog sticks is a welcomed addition. The soundtrack during the levels are pretty sweet. So I still have to recommend it if you're a Trials fan, but I'd wait till i goes down in price.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												(Please note that I am downvoting this as a sequel if you have played previous Trials games. If you have never played a trials game before then you won't understand why i think this one is a failure so go ahead and play it.)As a standalone game this would be amazing. I'm a big fan of the Trials series (go to hell Uplay and Ubisoft with it). However this one just doesn't stand up to the previus installments. It's clear ubisoft was trying to appeal to the "new generation" with all the techno bits and futuristic looking backdrops, which I guess is standard for Ubisoft nowadays isn't it? I really like the solid color art style in other games like portal or Mirror's Edge, but it feels kind of out of place her. That's nto to say it's completely out of place as it still works. but as a long time player I miss the gritty and harsh art style of old. Just my preference though.*Important* If you were hoping to find those unforgetably cool tracks like the one's from Evolution and HD then you will be disappointed. The tracks leave something to be desired and I breezed through all of them fairly easily. There's no Castle Crash or Gigatrack or Archipeligo. I rememebr most if nto all the tracks from Trials HD and Evolution by simply hearing the name but i couldn't even tell you the names of th first few tracks in Fusion. This is rather big for me as I really wanted the memory hook that previous tracks had given me. They give each difficulty a general "Theme" for example the second area you unlock is supposed to be in the city but I couldn't be less enthusiastic about the environments. They just seem copy and pasted together and I turned off the audio because I didn't find "Cindy" or that pother guy i couldn't bother to remember the name of.If this sounds like I'm calling Ubiusoft out on being the dirtbags they so desperately desire to be then you may be on to something there. But I still LIKE the game I'm just not in love with it like i was the previous ones, and if a sequal can't superceed it's predocessors then it's a failure as a sequel.But I am sure we will see more of Trials as Ubisoft has made it clear that there are no such things as standalone games anymore.Go to hell Ubisoft and takle your piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥excuse for a "Client" with youAlso i would be nice if steam had a spell check, I knwo that's lazy but I'm legally blind so proof reading is too much of a hassle

												Well I didn't expect much out of this game... but I got it simply because I can always wind down with long easy Trials levels.Reading the reviews of this game, I knew it wasn't much, so I don't regret buying the game. However, I cannot recommend buying this if you are looking for a good Trials game.It is buggy, some levels are unbearably laggy (bad optimization) and the "skill games" from the previous Trials game are baaaack! And even more annoying than ever! If you want to play with keyboard, don't bother trying to do anything with those games. Ubisoft themselves wrote that they were designed for pad. But, these games are so lame that I can't be bothered configuring my pad.The levels (when they aren't laggy) are bland. There is no challenge. I play this game when I want to wind down... It's good for that. But if you are looking for a Trials challenge, you won't find it here.Also, you need to pay much more to get the other half of this game (DLC) and there is no multiplayer.

												If you're a fan of motorcycle racing or motorcycles in general, you should love this game. 												__________________________8/10____________________________            Trials Fusion is a great game.  Lots of fun to be had for anyone looking for a bit of a challenge.  Overall, i cannot complain much about the game for the way it runs.  The graphics aren't super next-gen amazing-ness, but they still are pretty, and in my opinion as good as it needs to be for this style game.  I've had one crash, and I'm not convinced it was the game's fault.         As compared to the last few Trials games, it still features great challenges and a darned good selection of community maps, which gives this game near infinite playability if you enjoy how the mechanics work.  Trials has always been about challenges an lunacy to me, and while Fusion may not feature as much as the lunacy as the previous games, the challenges are abundant and ready for you to make a controller shaped dent in something near you.  When i speak of this lunacy being missing, in the last trials game i was always happy with how the maps, and events always caught you off gaurd, and said "Hey, so what if there's a war going on and a nuclear shark just tried to shoot you with laser beams, ride your bike fast ad hard!!!".  Personally, fusion lacked this kick-in-the-groin lunacy i loved so much from the previous games.        Overall, Trials Fusion will offer you hours of challenging fun, but at times, may take itself a little too seriously as compared to the previous installations to the franchise.

												Great difficulty and nice futuristic theme. Nonetheless, the motorcycles do not feel very futuristic.+infuriating difficulty+different behavior of the motorcycles match different level layouts+deep control system with emphasis on leaning the right way and breaking or accelerating at the right time; much deeper than those browser games+local multiplayer, sadly way more simplistic and uninspired than the single player levels-uplay-sometimes it is not very clear whenever a jump is a success or not because jumping often needs a special sequence of leaning inputs in a short ammount of time-stunt/trick system controls a bit wobbly as sometimes inputs are not accepted because of fast spinning (does that count as realism?)-game gets harder with your controller having a big deadzone. I cannot recommend Logitech devices-annoying menu design as it takes away from the futuristic theme and tries to sell you DLC all the time-game throws you out of a level if you need to many retries, erasing your checkpoint progressAll in all i can recommend this game despite it being an Ubisoft game. It is really fun after you finally are ingame and out of the disgusting and irritating menu screen.Keep in mind that this is the darksouls of motorcycle games so prepare to die.

Posted: April 19, 2016
												I have owned this game for 2 years now and I have played it on and off. I have been waiting to write this review since the I purchased Trials Fusion. I have now put 103 hours into Trials Fusion and I can finally say I have 100% completed the career. The emotional roller coaster I experienced while playing this game is unfathomable. Anger, joy, sadness. etc. the list continues for more words than are in my vocabulary. I'm sure that by this point my blood pressure is that of a 87 year old chain smoker, yet I don't mind. The satisfaction from completing a level or even improving a previous record is such an enlightening feeling. The rage and hatred that was once there is replaced by an abundance of good emotions. You battle no one but yourself, it is all a battle of your own skill. It takes away from the competitive nature of so many games and brings you back to the basics of what a game should be, frustrating beyond belief but satisfying. Red Lynx has done an amazing job putting together Trials Fusion and I could not be happier with the game. 10/10 Buy this game!

												Summary: Trials Fusion is a platformer with a small twist, you're on a motorcycle. It makes the game very unique and very fun. There is a plot, but you don't need to pay attention to it to enjoy this game it just gives answers to some small questions, but if you do want to know the plot it is a very good one, it's just a tad hard to follow. The game takes place in the future which is not like any of the previous games which took place in the present, so it's an interesting change in setting.Cons:-This game is VERY difficult, not that it's a bad thing though just be prepared that once you get to the last area in this game you're gonna wanna put a bullet in your head.-The soundtrack, it's pretty "meh" the only song I really enjoyed is from the DLC, "Fire in the Deep" but sadly it's only used in that DLC to my knowledge...-The amount of DLC, it's almost comparable to some EA games which is kinda sad... come on Red Lynx... don't do dis-Requires you to play the mobile counter-part to get one costume set, of course this is just aesthetic but it still kinda annoys me that if I want a costume set I have to play their mobile games, this also leads to my next point...-MICRO-TRANSACTIONS, screw you Ubisoft... this game was fine with just regular in-game currency...Pros:-VERY ADDICTIVE, this game is fantastic and you'll constantly come back to it wanting to collect more challenges and medals... assuming you like a challenge.-A pretty interesting and dark story, without giving anything away the story in this is pretty surprising and defiantly adds a dark twist to the game... you can even find out more to the story through the mobile version of the game, "Trials Frontier".-Very good setting, compared to Trials Evolution this setting is way better in that it is much more colorful and lively.-Added more content than the last game, this game now includes tricks, a quad-bike, and actual characters unlike the last iteration.-With the exception of the first DLC, "Riders of the Rustlands" all of the DLC is fantastic and develops the story even more.Verdict: 8/10I think many of the negative reviews are too focused on comparing this game to the previous one and UPlay, which in all honesty, UPlay is not bad at all you just have to make an account and log in and you're set.If you like a challenging physics-based games I would strongly suggest you pick this up, it's defiantly worth it.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												This recommendation was a tough call. I ended up choosing no for some very key things in the game that just made it painful to play. But first the pros.>Good theme, like, they couldn't have done it better. The blend between nature and technology was blended perfectly and it does feel like it is part of a bigger universe.>Nice controls (more on that).>Frankly great graphics (again, more on that later).>Good menus.And now the cons. In the cons I will not be discussing Uplay. The DRM does cost you a few minutes in the beginning and (for other games) can be a huge pain. However, in this game, all you need to do is log in once when you first boot it up and it doesn't really bug you much after that.So, cons>For someone with a lower-end machine, this game will kill you. As I said, great graphics, but what it did to me was reduce the framerate down to almost nothing and made the game almost unplayable due to button lag. My pc isn't terrible, either. It can play almost all games above 60fps and only goes this low for games like Next Car Game (which is an excellent game), and even for that it still gets 15-20fps.>Multiplayer is a pain, unlike the previous ones where it was a huge part of the experience.>Lack of content, which other people have commented on.>"Season pass," which is required to add what content the game should have had in the begining. Plus DLC, which I am generally against unless it's something like the gods and kings expansion pack. Basically, its just Ubisoft being Ubisoft.And thats pretty much it. If you are someone who has seen trials videos and wants to get in on it, pick Trials Evolution Gold Edition. It is better in most ways and equal when it isn't. If you have been a fan of the trials series ever since it started, go on right ahead. The main con for me is circumstantial, so if you are really dedicated you can have fun with the game despite the other flaws.Edit: Forgot about the "More on controls." Basically the only thing that I was going to say on that was that the game implemented a trick system that really doesn't contribute to the game at all. A few challenges may use it but most of the time it just gets in the way, especially during the tutorial levels.

												  Just like it's previous versions, Trials Fusion delivers challening and fun tracks that test you mentally, with satasfying results with each medal you get. For those who don't know, Trials is a game about clearing challenging tracks with Bikes as fast as possible with as few faults as possible. You gain medals and coin that go to getting you new cosmetic items for your bike and rider, and well as unlocking further tracks for you to play. In Fusion, you now no longer have to just do trials tracks, but also FMX, where you can combo tricks on your bike, building up score in the attempt to get a higher medal.  I have this game for both the Xbox 360 and Steam, and have already put quite a few hours into it. I am most definitely content with the game, and the future it holds. It runs smoothely (In windowed, I get some frame drops), without any issues when I have other programs up, and even though it has Uplay, I don't get any of the issues I have with Assassins Creed Black Flag.   I definitely recommend this game, and enjoy it far more than I did with the previous installments. 9/10

												I want to start off with the good parts of this game. I played the previous Trials games on the console and I was hoping that I could continue the series on PC. To an extent, I did. The gameplay was as I remember, i.e., incredibly addicting and rewarding. If you were to compare stills of this game to the previous games, you could tell it looks incredibly better. I'm not implying that I'm running a powerful system (my graphics card being a Radeon HD 7870), but compared to the smooth 60 fps I can maintain on medium settings in Metro: Last Light and Bioshock Infinity, I found the 40 fps and often 20 fps on low settings to be COMPLETELY absurd. I'm quite offended that the developers put less care to the PC version but I suppose it's my fault for assuming otherwise from Ubisoft. Although I do enjoy playing the game on occasion, I cannot recommend it to anyone without a more powerful system. The low fps is more than nauseating as usual but actually disruptive in the gameplay. Please play the demo, which I'm very grateful is provided, before thinking of purchasing it; something I was too anxious to do.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												NOTE: This is a long, detailed review. Longness may occur past this point.I had never played a Trials game before, but was familiar with the series, so I bought Fusion before the Summer Sale ended. I figured I'd be playing it a lot over the summer and as a general timewaster, so I bought the Season Pass with it, for a total of $30.Honestly, I feel like I've wasted my money buying this game.Having never played any other Trials games, I have nothing to compare the gameplay of Fusion against. I do know that it has no online multiplayer, which is a major disappointment. Looking through other reviews, I can see that the game is apparently lacking in other places (lack of tracks, buggy trick system, etc.), but again, I have nothing to compare it against, so I can't verify these claims. In my 2 hours of playing, the core gameplay has been solid. However, it's been mostly unenjoyable, which brings me to my first major quip with this game:1. The game is horribly optimizedI started up my game to my rider rising up an elevator in the first tutorial level. It was going pretty slowly, maybe for dramatic effect. And then the slowness carried on through the level. and the next one after that. What was the problem behind this? It turns out Trials Fusion is hellbent on running at 60 FPS. If you can't run it at 60 FPS, the game merely slows itself down until every in-game second has 60 frames. The result? If you run it at 40 FPS, every 3 real-life seconds becomes 2 seconds in-game. 30 FPS? Your game runs at half-speed. 20 FPS? A minute-long tracks now takes 3 minutes to complete. Have you ever put an old game in your floppy disc drive of your computer and it runs at lightning speed because the game speed was tied to processor speed? Trials Fusion goes 15 years into the past to bring back this experience. And don't you worry, they thought of that one supercomputer that can run the game at 90 FPS, so the game caps at 60 FPS so it doesn't run away.All in all, after crippling the resolution, video settings, and everything else, the game ran at an average of 45 FPS for me, where it started off at 15. My GPU may not be the greatest in the world (AMD Radeon HD 7640G), but it gets the job done for every other game I've played at decently high settings. Trials Fusion at its lowest possible settings still brings my GPU to its knees.2. uPlay is a piece of crap and attempted to eat my computerA little backstory here. I bought Burnout Paradise during the 2013 Summer Sale. Upon launching, EA promted me to make on Origin account, which I did. They didn't bug me any further, and from then on, Burnout launched through Steam and my Origin log-in was confirmed after launching.So why is it that Trials Fusion requires you to install uPlay, and that launching Trials from Steam only launches uPlay? If I only had to make a uPlay account to play (like with Burnout!), it would be fine. But why do I need a second game-launcher just to accomplish the task of launching my game, Ubisoft? So launching Trials Fusion is clumsy and weird because it requires installing uPlay, which seems bad enough. For me, however, it was the start of my problems.A couple of days after installing TF, Flash videos stopped working, which required me to disable hardware acceleration to fix. Whatever, Flash is buggy anyway. And then weird black bars appeared near the top of the window when I was watching a Twitch stream. OK, maybe something is wrong here, so I'll run an antivirus scan. My computer crashed mid-scan, and then I got my first blue screen the next day. The day after that the most ominous thing of all happened. I was watching a video when it flipped to another screen that said, "You can activate your operating system under the Settings tab." I went back to the video, and minimized my screen to reveal that I could now see my OS and build in the lower-right hand corner of my desktop. At that point, I went to System Restore and got uPlay the hell out of my computer. It's been about a month since the restore, and to date, nothing nearly as spooky as the aforementioned things has happened again.SUMMARY/TL;DR:You may notice next to the thumbs-down that I have 2 hours logged playing this game. This is due to a combination of the problems mentioned above. In my short time playing Trials Fusion, the gameplay wasn't that good for me, because it didn't run at full-speed. I can imagine it would be a great game if the damn thing would run correctly and stop being so picky. Ubisoft has done a decent job patching their errors, adding things like "better" optimization and custom Supercross tracks. Until they fix the bigger things though, I can't say anything good about this game. In conclusion...-Only get this game if you're absolutely confident in your computer's specs, ESPECIALLY GPU-Don't expect online play anytime soon (because the poor slow-motion guy would be left behind...)-uPlay is a piece of crap-If your computer fights back after installing uPlay, you should listen to it-#4spooky-I like donuts :3

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Having played every Trials game since 2, i've seen the series go from warehouses to the great outdoors and now to the future and with every iteration, it gets better and better. Trials Fusion pretty much kept what made Evolution great and added a few things to keep it from being just another Trials game. Here's my verdict.The GOOD.-"WELCOME TO THE FUTURE....MAN, MACHINE, THE FUTURE!"...yeah MUCH better intro than "VROOM VROOM, im ready to go, time for the muh muh muh muh muh muhnday nitro!"-Trials and Tribulations: The easy to learn, hard to master gameplay is still here and still as good as its ever been.-HOLY EPIC PC PORT BATMAN!: Redlynx learned from their mistakes, a much better port than Evo was. No texture pop in, no long load times, no FPS studdering all while adding a lot of graphics options to cater to many different setups. Nothing but good, clean, beautiful visuals at 60fps.(up to 120 would've been great though)-Challenging: The new challenge system adds ALOT of replay value to each track, although after beating Inferno IV, i don't wanna ever do that again. But its nice to go back and do 15 backflips on a track or finding that secret entrance or play tennis with a penguin to get XP for that fancy body kit you want.Here's my Inferno IV results if you don't believe me: http://cloud-4.steampowered.com/ugc/3332972269309505928/43D7B8AAF0EA94C165A622603A4DBFCDEECC01C2/The MEH.-Tricky: The FMX system is nice...but finicky, i've used keyboard(my main setup) and a PS4 controller and no matter what i do, i can never get it to do the trick i want to do during FMX events(Especially the ones that ask you to do specific tricks), i can only do coffins...EVERY TIME! Frustrating at times but a neat little addition nonetheless.-From an easy stroll to a trip to hell: As a long time player, i've gained a bit of skill over the years. I can gold(and above) every track up to the Rainforest bit, with ease(minus challenges). But after that, man does it go from easy to hard in an instant, i feel like newcomers are gonna have more problems adjusting to the difficulty curve than i did. At first its all about high speed and looking cool, after the ATV section...its all about control and balance, ESPECIALLY after unlocking the Pit Viper.-Do i look pretty?: Customization options are here, but a bit lacking, you can't operate on individual bike parts anymore(in favor of body kits) the rider customization is Tiered and in different themes and you can only change out the helmet, the shirt and the legs. Which kinda sucks, but there's alot to unlock and each tier is better than the last.The BAAAAAD.-Aside from the FMX, there really isn't anything new.Conclusion: Its Trials, if you've never played one, do yourself a favor and pick this up, this is by far one of the best arcade series out there. If you're a fan and you needed more Trials, click that buy button.

												The Bad:- BEWARE, this uses DRM in the form of uPlay, and does not tell you this anywhere prior to purchasing despite what some have said; very, very misleading. - Having to sign into two separate accounts every time just to be able to play the game (Steam and uPlay).- uPlay achievements instead of Steam achievements, even though it was bought on Steam - again it tells you this nowhere prior to purchasing.- Game physics seem tempermental at times, especially compared to all previous games which were almost consistently correct e.g. your bike can clip into the world forcing you to crash every now and again, or random unexpected bounces or rotations that don't feel right.- Game feels slightly unfinished e.g. still no online capabilities, and bikes not loading at all in the bike selection screen.- A good few of the Individual track challenges are stupidly frustrating beyond belief.- Shorter tracks than previous games.- No custom resolutions.- Crosses the fine line between challenging and frustrating.The Good:- Significantly better visuals.- Customisation.- Individual Track Challenges.- Not a bad PC port.All in all the game is good and fun, albeit hair pullingly frustrating if you want to complete everything.
