content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Same old Trials, New Maps.  I fell in love with this series years ago on console, and for the most part this installment hasn't dissappointed me yet.  It's addictive. It's frustrating, but the feeling of satisfaction when you finally gold medal makes it worth the anger. The new FMX mode and 4-wheel drive vehicles add some slight variation to the old formula. The Community Track Creation has huge potential and some pretty good tracks have already been created, but sometimes the direction changes are clunky and completely throw off the feel of the tracks.If your framerate drops below 60 the game goes into slow motion mode, which can get really annoying, but with a decent pc and nothing running in the background that won't usually be a problem. Every other review has taken care of complaining about Uplay for me so I won't bother.  No Online MP, Local only (Something tells me we can expect to have to buy a "Online Multiplayer DLC Pack" in the near future).  "Season Pass" seems awful pricey (it costs as much as the base game) so the devs better be planning some massive DLC packs to justify that price, otherwise I'm passing on that for now.   The Commentator Audio gets VERY repetitive if you get stuck on a track.Overall, It's enjoyable with a few small flaws that can be easily looked past. If you liked any previous Trials games, or if it's on sale, you should definately buy it.

												I know I've only logged an hour into this game, but as a very big fan of physics-based games, I have to say this one was a let down for me. I'm not going to complain about Uplay or say that the game isn't optimised correctly, because it plays wonderfully on my system at 60 FPS, ultra settings. There's really not much to Trials Fusion other than balancing your bike over different types of bumps, landing your bike correctly, and occasionally flying through the air to the next part of the track. Now don't get me wrong, there are neat tricks, solid physics, and a great presentation along with beautiful graphics. But even on sale like I got it, I'd say the $15-20 isn't worth it. Maybe at $5. If you want an awesome physics-based game where you do more than just grind through levels by shifting your weight on a bike to get over giant hills, etc., then I'd recommend you go play Happy Wheels. It's free, you can play it on flash, there is a far greater variety in vehicles/stages, and it's just more entertaining. I really love Ubisoft, but I have to say pass on this one.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Like Tetrix, some game excels because of its simplicity. It is so true for the Trials series. The goal of the game is simple, to get your bike from point A to point B as fast as possible without crashing, and all the controls you have is accelerate, break, leaning forward and back. However, the game gets challenging very fast and you always want to try again just to chip a few millisecond or to manage that difficult jump.Compares to its predecessors, Fusion offer a cleaner, more futuristic setting. Some players will miss the more gritty setting of Trials Evolution. The game offers nicer lighting, some neat bloom effects, and nice post-processing effects. Overall the graphic is very beautiful and crashes are spectacular.The game add a few new twists like being able to pull tricks with your right thumbstick. I find it a shame they add this feature and yet removed the ability to share replays on Youtube. What is the point of pulling spectacular stunts yet unable to show off to others? Likewise, there is no longer online multiplayer, which is promised again and again by the developer but no ETA is in sight. Given there are already 2 DLCs released you can tell the developer is focusing their efforts on making money instead of finishing the multiplayer feature of the game. There is local multiplayer you can play with your buddy on the same sceen.You can also make your own tracks, and at the writing of this review there are already over two thousands user generated tracks online, and many of them are top quality and add to the longitivity of the game. Which is necessary because there are much fewer tracks than Trial Evolution Gold. Again, I feel the developers are holding off the initial release of tracks to sell them as future DLCs, which BTW at 4.99$ for 10 tracks is quite pricy.Gameplay wise the official tracks are well designed but most of them are shorter than TEG. I find there are some twicks to the physics and overall a bit more forgiving than TEG. You can also make 1 or 2 faults and still get Gold on some tracks which I like because it is less frustrating, but I can see hard-core player won't like the change.Overall, I'd still recommand the game just because the overall concept is awesome. However, I don't like the business practice of the developer and would recommand you to get the game when on sale, where you can get the main game and the season pass as one package within reasonable price.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												NOTE: This is a long, detailed review. Longness may occur past this point.I had never played a Trials game before, but was familiar with the series, so I bought Fusion before the Summer Sale ended. I figured I'd be playing it a lot over the summer and as a general timewaster, so I bought the Season Pass with it, for a total of $30.Honestly, I feel like I've wasted my money buying this game.Having never played any other Trials games, I have nothing to compare the gameplay of Fusion against. I do know that it has no online multiplayer, which is a major disappointment. Looking through other reviews, I can see that the game is apparently lacking in other places (lack of tracks, buggy trick system, etc.), but again, I have nothing to compare it against, so I can't verify these claims. In my 2 hours of playing, the core gameplay has been solid. However, it's been mostly unenjoyable, which brings me to my first major quip with this game:1. The game is horribly optimizedI started up my game to my rider rising up an elevator in the first tutorial level. It was going pretty slowly, maybe for dramatic effect. And then the slowness carried on through the level. and the next one after that. What was the problem behind this? It turns out Trials Fusion is hellbent on running at 60 FPS. If you can't run it at 60 FPS, the game merely slows itself down until every in-game second has 60 frames. The result? If you run it at 40 FPS, every 3 real-life seconds becomes 2 seconds in-game. 30 FPS? Your game runs at half-speed. 20 FPS? A minute-long tracks now takes 3 minutes to complete. Have you ever put an old game in your floppy disc drive of your computer and it runs at lightning speed because the game speed was tied to processor speed? Trials Fusion goes 15 years into the past to bring back this experience. And don't you worry, they thought of that one supercomputer that can run the game at 90 FPS, so the game caps at 60 FPS so it doesn't run away.All in all, after crippling the resolution, video settings, and everything else, the game ran at an average of 45 FPS for me, where it started off at 15. My GPU may not be the greatest in the world (AMD Radeon HD 7640G), but it gets the job done for every other game I've played at decently high settings. Trials Fusion at its lowest possible settings still brings my GPU to its knees.2. uPlay is a piece of crap and attempted to eat my computerA little backstory here. I bought Burnout Paradise during the 2013 Summer Sale. Upon launching, EA promted me to make on Origin account, which I did. They didn't bug me any further, and from then on, Burnout launched through Steam and my Origin log-in was confirmed after launching.So why is it that Trials Fusion requires you to install uPlay, and that launching Trials from Steam only launches uPlay? If I only had to make a uPlay account to play (like with Burnout!), it would be fine. But why do I need a second game-launcher just to accomplish the task of launching my game, Ubisoft? So launching Trials Fusion is clumsy and weird because it requires installing uPlay, which seems bad enough. For me, however, it was the start of my problems.A couple of days after installing TF, Flash videos stopped working, which required me to disable hardware acceleration to fix. Whatever, Flash is buggy anyway. And then weird black bars appeared near the top of the window when I was watching a Twitch stream. OK, maybe something is wrong here, so I'll run an antivirus scan. My computer crashed mid-scan, and then I got my first blue screen the next day. The day after that the most ominous thing of all happened. I was watching a video when it flipped to another screen that said, "You can activate your operating system under the Settings tab." I went back to the video, and minimized my screen to reveal that I could now see my OS and build in the lower-right hand corner of my desktop. At that point, I went to System Restore and got uPlay the hell out of my computer. It's been about a month since the restore, and to date, nothing nearly as spooky as the aforementioned things has happened again.SUMMARY/TL;DR:You may notice next to the thumbs-down that I have 2 hours logged playing this game. This is due to a combination of the problems mentioned above. In my short time playing Trials Fusion, the gameplay wasn't that good for me, because it didn't run at full-speed. I can imagine it would be a great game if the damn thing would run correctly and stop being so picky. Ubisoft has done a decent job patching their errors, adding things like "better" optimization and custom Supercross tracks. Until they fix the bigger things though, I can't say anything good about this game. In conclusion...-Only get this game if you're absolutely confident in your computer's specs, ESPECIALLY GPU-Don't expect online play anytime soon (because the poor slow-motion guy would be left behind...)-uPlay is a piece of crap-If your computer fights back after installing uPlay, you should listen to it-#4spooky-I like donuts :3

												I want to start off with the good parts of this game. I played the previous Trials games on the console and I was hoping that I could continue the series on PC. To an extent, I did. The gameplay was as I remember, i.e., incredibly addicting and rewarding. If you were to compare stills of this game to the previous games, you could tell it looks incredibly better. But after I got past the introductory phase, I started realising how annoying logging into Uplay was. I also ran into frame rate problems. I'm not implying that I'm running a powerful system (my graphics card being a Radeon HD 7870), but compared to the smooth 60 fps I can maintain on medium settings in Metro: Last Light and Bioshock Infinity, I found the 40 fps and often 20 fps on low settings to be COMPLETELY absurd. I'm quite offended that the developers put less care to the PC version but I suppose it's my fault for assuming otherwise from Ubisoft. Although I do enjoy playing the game on occasion, I cannot recommend it to anyone without a more powerful system. The low fps is more than nauseating as usual but actually disruptive in the gameplay. Please play the demo, which I'm very grateful is provided, before thinking of purchasing it; something I was too anxious to do.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												I feel like you have to know what Trials is before you play it. If you don't, you might be very surprised after playing it for a bit. The first set of levels are simple and enjoyable. The middle ones are pretty tough. The final tracks will frustrate the hell out of you. Some tracks are normal trials, then others are stunt tracks and mini games. Most of the tracks have 3 bonus challenges, so there are reasons to go back and revisit all of them. You can also try to beat your friends times (and scores I think) on each track.I haven't even downloaded any player created courses yet, but I know from playing Trials Evolution on Xbox 360 that people make some crazy stuff to play.I think most people can enjoy this game. The controls are simple, but challenging to perfect in the later levels. The game provides a great challenge for people, but casual players can enjoy it too.

												I bought Trials Fusion when it came on sale a week after I first tried my first Trials game (Trials Evolution Gold). It was a pleasant upgrade in graphics and gameplay and I am quite in love with this game. It has a range of levels across many beautiful vistas. I enjoy the skill games that throw some extra spice into the regular levels. Hitting those jumps perfectly can be amazingly satisfying.A+, I love this game, buy it now.Pros:1.	Hundreds of free tracks online2.	A range of difficulties to suit everybody3.	Online and local multiplayer (I am talking split screen!)4.	In game track builder5.	Character/Bike customization and unlockables6.	Sweet sweet Trials game play7.	Best Trials graphics to dateCons:1.	None come to mind, BUY THIS GAME

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I love this game. I have more hours offline than what my account shows. This was my first experience with Trials series (I did play Evo after this game to compare) and between the two, they are fairly equal. This game offers better graphics than Evo and the challenges are fun to complete as well. I went ahead and purchased the season pass as well (for $16 for the game plus all dlc, can't complain). This is not an easy game by any means, and to be honest, this game (as straight forward as it is) SHOULD be a boring game. However, it's not even close! I can spend 30 minutes perfecting a 40 second track, trying to complete the challenges, restarting the level 100 times, blah blah blah, AND still love doing it. It is exciting, fast paced and gives you a good laugh. You will get frustrated from time to time, but I can't think of a game where I haven't been. I have been having some issues connecting to multiplayer, so for that reason I would score this a 9.5/10. If Evo goes on sale ever as well, I will be purchasing that one too. If you are new to the series, then I recommend 100%. If you are a seasoned player, I suggest reading other players reviews and deciding off of their reviews as I have not had enough time yet to get into the heart of the game.

content:
Posted: January 25
												Great difficulty and nice futuristic theme. Nonetheless, the motorcycles do not feel very futuristic.+infuriating difficulty+different behavior of the motorcycles match different level layouts+deep control system with emphasis on leaning the right way and breaking or accelerating at the right time; much deeper than those browser games+local multiplayer, sadly way more simplistic and uninspired than the single player levels-uplay-sometimes it is not very clear whenever a jump is a success or not because jumping often needs a special sequence of leaning inputs in a short ammount of time-stunt/trick system controls a bit wobbly as sometimes inputs are not accepted because of fast spinning (does that count as realism?)-game gets harder with your controller having a big deadzone. I cannot recommend Logitech devices-annoying menu design as it takes away from the futuristic theme and tries to sell you DLC all the time-game throws you out of a level if you need to many retries, erasing your checkpoint progressAll in all i can recommend this game despite it being an Ubisoft game. It is really fun after you finally are ingame and out of the disgusting and irritating menu screen.Keep in mind that this is the darksouls of motorcycle games so prepare to die.
